title: How to Make Studded Jewelry

steps.headline: Choose a durable fabric to use for your bracelet.
steps.description: Go to your local craft or fabric store and pick up less than 1 yard (0.91 m) of fabric for your bracelet. To make your studded jewelry especially durable, use denim or faux leather as the base. If you don’t mind spending some extra money, you can try making your bracelet with real leather.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of fabric that’s longer than the length of your wrist.
steps.description: Take a short length of measuring tape and wrap it around your wrist. Add a ½ in (1.3 cm) to the total circumference, then mark this updated measurement along the material that you’ll use for your bracelet. Make this section of material as wide as you’d like—just know that later on, you’ll be trimming it down. If you’d like to make a studded cuff bracelet, leave your bracelet 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm).

steps.headline: Press a stud into the material to start a pattern.
steps.description: Take a rounded or squared stud and arrange it along the center of your fabric. Apply a moderate amount of force to insert the stud into the material. Once you’ve pressed in the stud, turn the material over to check that the bottom stud spike is visible. Apply extra pressure when using thicker bracelet material. You can purchase studs online or at a craft store. Did you know? Studs are spiky pieces of metal that can pierce through different kinds of fabric. They tend to be squared off or rounded, and are usually silver or gold. These items are able to stay in place due to the 4 teeth protruding from the back of the stud.

steps.headline: Repeat this process by sticking additional studs in the material.
steps.description: Take a second stud and stick it into the fabric, keeping it in line with the first stud. Use the same amount of force to press this trinket into the fabric, then continue adding more studs in a straight line. For a streamlined look, try keeping the studs flush with one another. If you’d like an edgier look, try separating the metal pieces by 1 in (2.5 cm). Feel free to experiment with the spacing on your own bracelet.

steps.headline: Trim away any excess material to create a thin bracelet.
steps.description: If you have a lot of extra fabric, cut it away so there’s less than ½ in (1.3 cm) of material on each side of the stud line. If you’d prefer to make a studded cuff, don’t trim away any of the material.

steps.headline: Glue in the excess material behind the studs.
steps.description: Squeeze a line of hot glue beneath the remaining extra fabric. Fold the material behind the studs and press on it for 3 seconds, so the material stays in place. Next, glue the other section of fabric behind the studs as well. If you’re making a cuff bracelet, only fold and glue ¼ to ½ in (0.6 to 1.2 cm) of the material behind the studs on each side of the bracelet.

steps.headline: Attach two 4 in (10 cm) lengths of cord to the ends of the bracelet with hot glue.
steps.description:
Squeeze a dot of hot glue onto 1 end of the bracelet, then stick 1 piece of string or cord onto the glue. Repeat the same process by gluing and securing another piece of string on the opposite side of the bracelet. Once the glue dries, use these strings to tie off or adjust your studded bracelet
Try to use a small, pea-sized amount of hot glue, so it won’t be as visible on the bracelet. When it’s finished, the bracelet will look like a thin row of studs.

steps.headline: Measure the size of your neck before making a choker.
steps.description: Take a section of measuring tape and wrap it around your neck. Use 2 fingers to pinch the tape in place, so you can remove it and see your exact measurement. Jot down your neck’s circumference on a piece of scrap paper so you can have it on hand. If you’re having difficulty making the measurement yourself, feel free to ask a friend or family member for assistance.

steps.headline: Trim a piece of material that matches your neck’s circumference.
steps.description: Mark off your neck measurement onto a section of leather, so your choker won’t be too loose. Once you’ve made these markings, cut out the exact dimensions of your choker from a section of leather with a fair of fabric scissors. Leather or faux leather are great options for a choker. If you’d prefer something thinner and softer, try using suede or velvet instead. You can make your choker as wide or as thin as you’d like. If you’d like to save time, try buying an undecorated leather collar online.

steps.headline: Use an awl to create holes that are 1½ in (3.8 cm) apart.
steps.description: Place a ruler beneath your blank leather choker. After measuring off small, 1½ in (3.8 cm) sections, poke a pinprick-sized hole into the center of the leather. Continue along the length of the choker, creating small holes that the studs can fit through. If you’d like to create a more streamlined design, try arranging the studs closer together.

steps.headline: Stick your awl through the holes to make them larger.
steps.description: Pick up the leather choker and push the awl through the first hole. Twist the tool to make the indentation wider, so the stud can fit into the choker more easily. Repeat this motion with all the poked holes, so your crafting process can go more smoothly. The widened holes in the leather will be about 2-3 millimeters wide.

steps.headline: Press your studs carefully into the leather strip.
steps.description: Take your rounded or squared studs and insert 1 stud into each opening. Apply a moderate amount of pressure as you push the in each stud, so the metal can penetrate the leather completely. Your studs might have spikes protruding from the back of the leather, which is normal.Tip: If you’d like to create an edgier choker, use spikes instead of studs.

steps.headline: Push the backing spikes downward with the bottom of a pen.
steps.description: Flip the leather strip over and find 4 small spikes sticking out beneath the material. To prevent these spikes from scratching your neck, use the bottom of a pen to push them into a horizontal position. Continue pressing along these spikes until they’re no longer protruding from the leather. While these spikes shouldn’t be too difficult to bend, you might need to apply a little extra force with the pen to secure them into place.

steps.headline: Use pliers to secure metal clamps on both ends of the choker.
steps.description: Pick up a small, metal clamp and clip it onto 1 end of the choker. Pinch the end of the clamp with the pliers to tighten it, which helps keep it attached to the choker. Once 1 clamp is in place, use the pliers to attach and tighten a clamp on the opposite end of the choker. These clamps look like small, silver squares. You can purchase them at your local craft store.

steps.headline: Attach a metal connecting ring and clasp to 1 of the clamps.
steps.description: Open a connecting ring with a pair of pliers, then slide the fish-claw clasp onto the ring. Using your pliers, attach this clasp and ring to 1 of the metal clamps. You can find these materials at your local craft store in the jewelry-making section. Generally, these rings are only a few millimeters wide.

steps.headline: Clip a chain extension to the opposite clamp.
steps.description: Pick up a chain link jewelry extension with your pliers and attach it to the opposite choker clamp. Use this extension chain to tighten or loosen your choker after you secure the jewelry around your neck. To fully connect the necklace, unhook the fish-claw clasp and hook it onto 1 of the chains. You can find these extensions at any craft store.

text:
Creating Stud Bracelets Choose a durable fabric to use for your bracelet. Go to your local craft or fabric store and pick up less than 1 yard (0.91 m) of fabric for your bracelet. To make your studded jewelry especially durable, use denim or faux leather as the base. If you don’t mind spending some extra money, you can try making your bracelet with real leather. Cut a piece of fabric that’s longer than the length of your wrist. Take a short length of measuring tape and wrap it around your wrist. Add a ½ in (1.3 cm) to the total circumference, then mark this updated measurement along the material that you’ll use for your bracelet. Make this section of material as wide as you’d like—just know that later on, you’ll be trimming it down. If you’d like to make a studded cuff bracelet, leave your bracelet 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm). Press a stud into the material to start a pattern. Take a rounded or squared stud and arrange it along the center of your fabric. Apply a moderate amount of force to insert the stud into the material. Once you’ve pressed in the stud, turn the material over to check that the bottom stud spike is visible. Apply extra pressure when using thicker bracelet material. You can purchase studs online or at a craft store. Did you know? Studs are spiky pieces of metal that can pierce through different kinds of fabric. They tend to be squared off or rounded, and are usually silver or gold. These items are able to stay in place due to the 4 teeth protruding from the back of the stud. Repeat this process by sticking additional studs in the material. Take a second stud and stick it into the fabric, keeping it in line with the first stud. Use the same amount of force to press this trinket into the fabric, then continue adding more studs in a straight line. For a streamlined look, try keeping the studs flush with one another. If you’d like an edgier look, try separating the metal pieces by 1 in (2.5 cm). Feel free to experiment with the spacing on your own bracelet. Trim away any excess material to create a thin bracelet. If you have a lot of extra fabric, cut it away so there’s less than ½ in (1.3 cm) of material on each side of the stud line. If you’d prefer to make a studded cuff, don’t trim away any of the material. Glue in the excess material behind the studs. Squeeze a line of hot glue beneath the remaining extra fabric. Fold the material behind the studs and press on it for 3 seconds, so the material stays in place. Next, glue the other section of fabric behind the studs as well. If you’re making a cuff bracelet, only fold and glue ¼ to ½ in (0.6 to 1.2 cm) of the material behind the studs on each side of the bracelet. Attach two 4 in (10 cm) lengths of cord to the ends of the bracelet with hot glue. Squeeze a dot of hot glue onto 1 end of the bracelet, then stick 1 piece of string or cord onto the glue. Repeat the same process by gluing and securing another piece of string on the opposite side of the bracelet. Once the glue dries, use these strings to tie off or adjust your studded bracelet
Try to use a small, pea-sized amount of hot glue, so it won’t be as visible on the bracelet. When it’s finished, the bracelet will look like a thin row of studs. Crafting a Choker with Studs Measure the size of your neck before making a choker. Take a section of measuring tape and wrap it around your neck. Use 2 fingers to pinch the tape in place, so you can remove it and see your exact measurement. Jot down your neck’s circumference on a piece of scrap paper so you can have it on hand. If you’re having difficulty making the measurement yourself, feel free to ask a friend or family member for assistance. Trim a piece of material that matches your neck’s circumference. Mark off your neck measurement onto a section of leather, so your choker won’t be too loose. Once you’ve made these markings, cut out the exact dimensions of your choker from a section of leather with a fair of fabric scissors. Leather or faux leather are great options for a choker. If you’d prefer something thinner and softer, try using suede or velvet instead. You can make your choker as wide or as thin as you’d like. If you’d like to save time, try buying an undecorated leather collar online. Use an awl to create holes that are 1½ in (3.8 cm) apart. Place a ruler beneath your blank leather choker. After measuring off small, 1½ in (3.8 cm) sections, poke a pinprick-sized hole into the center of the leather. Continue along the length of the choker, creating small holes that the studs can fit through. If you’d like to create a more streamlined design, try arranging the studs closer together. Stick your awl through the holes to make them larger. Pick up the leather choker and push the awl through the first hole. Twist the tool to make the indentation wider, so the stud can fit into the choker more easily. Repeat this motion with all the poked holes, so your crafting process can go more smoothly. The widened holes in the leather will be about 2-3 millimeters wide. Press your studs carefully into the leather strip. Take your rounded or squared studs and insert 1 stud into each opening. Apply a moderate amount of pressure as you push the in each stud, so the metal can penetrate the leather completely. Your studs might have spikes protruding from the back of the leather, which is normal.Tip: If you’d like to create an edgier choker, use spikes instead of studs. Push the backing spikes downward with the bottom of a pen. Flip the leather strip over and find 4 small spikes sticking out beneath the material. To prevent these spikes from scratching your neck, use the bottom of a pen to push them into a horizontal position. Continue pressing along these spikes until they’re no longer protruding from the leather. While these spikes shouldn’t be too difficult to bend, you might need to apply a little extra force with the pen to secure them into place. Use pliers to secure metal clamps on both ends of the choker. Pick up a small, metal clamp and clip it onto 1 end of the choker. Pinch the end of the clamp with the pliers to tighten it, which helps keep it attached to the choker. Once 1 clamp is in place, use the pliers to attach and tighten a clamp on the opposite end of the choker. These clamps look like small, silver squares. You can purchase them at your local craft store. Attach a metal connecting ring and clasp to 1 of the clamps. Open a connecting ring with a pair of pliers, then slide the fish-claw clasp onto the ring. Using your pliers, attach this clasp and ring to 1 of the metal clamps. You can find these materials at your local craft store in the jewelry-making section. Generally, these rings are only a few millimeters wide. Clip a chain extension to the opposite clamp. Pick up a chain link jewelry extension with your pliers and attach it to the opposite choker clamp. Use this extension chain to tighten or loosen your choker after you secure the jewelry around your neck. To fully connect the necklace, unhook the fish-claw clasp and hook it onto 1 of the chains. You can find these extensions at any craft store.
sentences: Creating Stud Bracelets Choose a durable fabric to use for your bracelet.
Go to your local craft or fabric store and pick up less than 1 yard (0.91 m) of fabric for your bracelet.
To make your studded jewelry especially durable, use denim or faux leather as the base.
If you don’t mind spending some extra money, you can try making your bracelet with real leather.
Cut a piece of fabric that’s longer than the length of your wrist.
Take a short length of measuring tape and wrap it around your wrist.
Add a ½ in (1.3 cm) to the total circumference, then mark this updated measurement along the material that you’ll use for your bracelet.
Make this section of material as wide as you’d like—just know that later on, you’ll be trimming it down.
If you’d like to make a studded cuff bracelet, leave your bracelet 3 to 4 in (7.6 to 10.2 cm).
Press a stud into the material to start a pattern.
Take a rounded or squared stud and arrange it along the center of your fabric.
Apply a moderate amount of force to insert the stud into the material.
Once you’ve pressed in the stud, turn the material over to check that the bottom stud spike is visible.
Apply extra pressure when using thicker bracelet material.
You can purchase studs online or at a craft store.
Did you know?
Studs are spiky pieces of metal that can pierce through different kinds of fabric.
They tend to be squared off or rounded, and are usually silver or gold.
These items are able to stay in place due to the 4 teeth protruding from the back of the stud.
Repeat this process by sticking additional studs in the material.
Take a second stud and stick it into the fabric, keeping it in line with the first stud.
Use the same amount of force to press this trinket into the fabric, then continue adding more studs in a straight line.
For a streamlined look, try keeping the studs flush with one another.
If you’d like an edgier look, try separating the metal pieces by 1 in (2.5 cm).
Feel free to experiment with the spacing on your own bracelet.
Trim away any excess material to create a thin bracelet.
If you have a lot of extra fabric, cut it away so there’s less than ½ in (1.3 cm) of material on each side of the stud line.
If you’d prefer to make a studded cuff, don’t trim away any of the material.
Glue in the excess material behind the studs.
Squeeze a line of hot glue beneath the remaining extra fabric.
Fold the material behind the studs and press on it for 3 seconds, so the material stays in place.
Next, glue the other section of fabric behind the studs as well.
If you’re making a cuff bracelet, only fold and glue ¼ to ½ in (0.6 to 1.2 cm) of the material behind the studs on each side of the bracelet.
Attach two 4 in (10 cm) lengths of cord to the ends of the bracelet with hot glue.
Squeeze a dot of hot glue onto 1 end of the bracelet, then stick 1 piece of string or cord onto the glue.
Repeat the same process by gluing and securing another piece of string on the opposite side of the bracelet.

Once the glue dries, use these strings to tie off or adjust your studded bracelet
Try to use a small, pea-sized amount of hot glue, so it won’t be as visible on the bracelet.
When it’s finished, the bracelet will look like a thin row of studs.
Crafting a Choker with Studs Measure the size of your neck before making a choker.
Take a section of measuring tape and wrap it around your neck.
Use 2 fingers to pinch the tape in place, so you can remove it and see your exact measurement.
Jot down your neck’s circumference on a piece of scrap paper so you can have it on hand.
If you’re having difficulty making the measurement yourself, feel free to ask a friend or family member for assistance.
Trim a piece of material that matches your neck’s circumference.
Mark off your neck measurement onto a section of leather, so your choker won’t be too loose.
Once you’ve made these markings, cut out the exact dimensions of your choker from a section of leather with a fair of fabric scissors.
Leather or faux leather are great options for a choker.
If you’d prefer something thinner and softer, try using suede or velvet instead.
You can make your choker as wide or as thin as you’d like.
If you’d like to save time, try buying an undecorated leather collar online.
Use an awl to create holes that are 1½ in (3.8 cm) apart.
Place a ruler beneath your blank leather choker.
After measuring off small, 1½ in (3.8 cm) sections, poke a pinprick-sized hole into the center of the leather.
Continue along the length of the choker, creating small holes that the studs can fit through.
If you’d like to create a more streamlined design, try arranging the studs closer together.
Stick your awl through the holes to make them larger.
Pick up the leather choker and push the awl through the first hole.
Twist the tool to make the indentation wider, so the stud can fit into the choker more easily.
Repeat this motion with all the poked holes, so your crafting process can go more smoothly.
The widened holes in the leather will be about 2-3 millimeters wide.
Press your studs carefully into the leather strip.
Take your rounded or squared studs and insert 1 stud into each opening.
Apply a moderate amount of pressure as you push the in each stud, so the metal can penetrate the leather completely.
Your studs might have spikes protruding from the back of the leather, which is normal.Tip: If you’d like to create an edgier choker, use spikes instead of studs.
Push the backing spikes downward with the bottom of a pen.
Flip the leather strip over and find 4 small spikes sticking out beneath the material.
To prevent these spikes from scratching your neck, use the bottom of a pen to push them into a horizontal position.
Continue pressing along these spikes until they’re no longer protruding from the leather.
While these spikes shouldn’t be too difficult to bend, you might need to apply a little extra force with the pen to secure them into place.
Use pliers to secure metal clamps on both ends of the choker.
Pick up a small, metal clamp and clip it onto 1 end of the choker.
Pinch the end of the clamp with the pliers to tighten it, which helps keep it attached to the choker.
Once 1 clamp is in place, use the pliers to attach and tighten a clamp on the opposite end of the choker.
These clamps look like small, silver squares.
You can purchase them at your local craft store.
Attach a metal connecting ring and clasp to 1 of the clamps.
Open a connecting ring with a pair of pliers, then slide the fish-claw clasp onto the ring.
Using your pliers, attach this clasp and ring to 1 of the metal clamps.
You can find these materials at your local craft store in the jewelry-making section.
Generally, these rings are only a few millimeters wide.
Clip a chain extension to the opposite clamp.
Pick up a chain link jewelry extension with your pliers and attach it to the opposite choker clamp.
Use this extension chain to tighten or loosen your choker after you secure the jewelry around your neck.
To fully connect the necklace, unhook the fish-claw clasp and hook it onto 1 of the chains.
You can find these extensions at any craft store.
